description: From bee +â€Ž line, due to the belief that a bee returns to its hive in a straight course, originally an Americanism.

entries.meaning: A very direct or quick path or trip.
examples: to make / strike a beeline for / to something
The children made a beeline to the swimming pool.

entries.meaning: (mining, chiefly historical) A dynamite fuse made with a small quantity of dynamite powder along its length, so that the spark travels quickly and at a specific known rate.

verbs.description: beeline (third-person singular simple present beelines, present participle beelining, simple past and past participle beelined)

entries.meaning: To travel in a straight line, ignoring established paths of travel.
